title: Location Conclusion
content:
First, the overall park-layout – an open lawn flanked by loose gravel “splitt” paths edged with simple wooden bollards – and the presence of public benches and ping-pong tables strongly match the municipal design of Luitpoldpark in Munich.  Munich maintains several of these small, freely accessible outdoor table-tennis installations, one of the most popular being in the southern section of Luitpoldpark near the Bamberger Haus café ([munich.travel](https://www.munich.travel/en/topics/sports-leisure/on-your-marks-get-set-go?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luitpoldpark?utm_source=chatgpt.com)).

Second, the under-renovation building behind the trees corresponds to one of the smaller service pavilions adjacent to the Bamberger Haus complex, which has been undergoing façade work in spring 2025 (visible in local community bulletins and temporary green scaffolding) ([muenchen.de](https://www.muenchen.de/en/sights/parks/luitpoldpark?utm_source=chatgpt.com)). The two external staircases, ground‐floor glass walls, and first‐floor glazing behind green safety mesh are characteristic of this utility wing rather than the neo-baroque main house itself.

Finally, the tree species (ginkgo, pyramidal oak, spring-blooming cherry) and overall mature canopy fit Luitpoldpark’s historic plantings, established in 1911 and maintained with a mix of native and decorative ornamentals ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luitpoldpark?utm_source=chatgpt.com)).

From these converging clues, I am confident the photo was taken in:

Luitpoldpark, Schwabing-West, Munich, Germany, Europe
